comments.commentBody: You can site any poll you want ... but as it stands right now she will destroy him .. and Bernie Sanders could beat him too ...

At last! A Modern Love column that is beautiful and true. Too many of these are shallow stories of relationships that have love in them, but say nothing deeply meaningful about what love is and how it works. One was about a submissive. Oh, please. Give us more about love!

This is so beautiful! "Love begets love." Yes, yes, yes! Taking risks, showing up, and asking questions that lead to connection,; this is "leading by love".
Thank you for your wonderful story, I can't wait to read your books.
Wow. Lovely article. Hope it happens to me some day. Thank you.

It's easy to give pregnant women advice ... harder for them to follow, especially if they are out there trying to make a living.  Bearing a healthy child should not require extraordinary measures, especially in this "civilized" nation.

There's a difference between fear and a prudence prompted by people who spend a lifetime studying a specific element of our modern life, a specific element that is man made and can be controlled with the blessing of an informed public. To project hysteria on a qualified messenger is a straw man argument and, given the emerging evidence, sneering at people's concern doesn't help solve the issue one bit.
I don't notice anyone on the "left" shooting up anyplace like a Birthright office for example. We have more to fear from these white, Christian crazies, than any Syrian refugee in my opinion.
That's what I thought, Emgee, but I think Blanche is right.

I believe your post is not quite accurate. As I have posted elsewhere here, I believe the cable companies are intentionally downgrading the signal from over the air stations, even though they have the capacity to carry the signal in full. The digital signal directly from a television station is itself compressed video, compressed to a data rate just above 19 megabits per second. The cable retransmission, however, looks to me to be at a lower data rate so they can, as you indicate, cram more channels onto their wires. This is a business decision, not a technical one. It is promoted, in part, I think by the fact that cable has to continue sending out SD versions of channels (duplicating HD) because a lot of people still don't have HD sets.

That over the air digital has huge problems with pixilation in many large cities and mountainous areas. "We' are being nickeled and dimed to death to buy cable, Netflix, Sires and the list goes on...It's all about making corporation more lucrative and the consumers poorer for what-entertainment?
I have season tickets to the opera, symphony and theater for plays. I'd rather spend my money on reality.

That over the air TV is digital, it is better because the signal is not compressed to save bandwidth.

It comes through clearer than the older analogue FM TV broadcast, as digital is not as subject to distortions in the radio wave. The receiver can recognize the 1s, and 0s even when the signal is weak. On cable the signal is compressed to allow more channels on the same cable, which can only carry a limited number of channels.

So my antenna with a small amplifier gets me all the major channels, and several others that I don't watch anyway. I do not get the big sports playoffs, but have not really missed them, and the advertisers miss me, so should I care?

I love my CDs as I play them while traveling in the car. As I am an opera fan, I can listen to my favorites and not have to listen to those awful pop singers, and rap crap of today. There is NPR, but it is not always available in places like Utah, or even Bakersfield.

I also have a good collection of 50s and 60s jazz recordings on LP, along with Beethoven. Brahms, Rachmaninoff, and other classical recordings.
The CDs have allowed me to listen to Verdi, Donizetti, Bellini, Puccini, Wagner, and others. it is hard to tell the difference between them, and the analogue recordings, you have to be an expert audiophile to hear it. But downloaded streaming music is terrible, as is cable TV.

Whatever his personal virtues, his decision earlier this year to kill the Baltimore region Red Line rail transit expansion, in the works for nearly 15 years under previous Republican and Democratic administrations, with tens of millions of dollars already spent and hundreds of millions of federal dollars committed, was penny wise and pound foolish. Coming as it did just weeks after the Baltimore riots, the announcement gave new meaning to the expression "adding insult to injury." Baltimore needs the Red Line. Gov. Hogan killed it.

17 wins in a row is a lot, but it is by no means unprecedented. There are 12 teams with longer streaks in NBA history, with 6 in the past 20 years. Just last year the Atlanta Hawks won 19.

That said, I agree with you on Kerr. Even though he is far from totally absent, he is at best an assistant.

Sorry this is so confusing but it's really very simple: the record set by the dubs -- now at 18 -- has been reached by no other NBA team, ever.  No. Other. Team.  Just the dubs.  Why?  Because this record is for consecutive wins FROM THE START OF THE SEASON...not consecutive wins.  Two teams previously got to 15 before losing their first game.  Getting to 16, and now 18, is unprecedented.  Atlanta has never done this, nor did 6 other teams in the past 20 years.  A streak is a streak.  But a record streak of no losses at the start of a season has been achieved by one team in NBA history, the dubs.  Coached by Steve Kerr, with second year assistant Luke Walton standing in during games, with Kerr at most practices and consulting with his assistants during halftime.  Kerr hired Walton as an assistant and picked him to fill in while he was out after back surgery.  None of this happens without Kerr, who true to form gives credit to others and out of respect for him we go along and applaud Walton, who to his credit, knows this all starts and ends with his boss.

For God's sake!

This is NOT rocket science!

Do you know of ANYONE OTHER than Luke Walton, who can (or has) strung together 17 National Basketball Association consecutive wins?

I like Steve Kerr- always have, but give credit where it is due- I don't think that Steve Kerr even wants to receive this type of acknowledgment- not even being there to 'coach'.

Give Walton his 'due'....HE did it, along with that marvelous congruence of talent.

Still, it is Walton and the current assistant staff that are managing this run- Are you saying that they could have carried this off without a coach; but just crediting Kerr's 'system'?

I don't buy that reasoning...And Curry, as good as he is, was/is not the coach...

The focus and contention on what is happening right now is if Walton should be acknowledged for his contribution to this run on a 'real-time', on-going basis basis.

Nothing is being taken away from Steve Kerr- he agrees with Walton's performance.

There are a number of reasons that the Warriors have attained this amazing historic win streak. But, in terms of coaching, to say that Luke Walton is more responsible for this win streak than Kerr would be wrong.  They are playing Kerr's system and continuing Kerr's program from last year.  If any one individual should get credit for this win streak other than Kerr, how about Curry? Steve Kerr should not be deprived of this historic record just because he was injured.  Coach Kerr is the COACH most responsible for this historic record and he richly deserves the coaching credit!

Take it from Steve Kerr himself. This is not spoken from a point of humility.., these are his quoted words...

“I’m sitting in the locker room and watching the games on TV, and I’m not even traveling to most of the road games,” Kerr said in advance of the team’s 16th win, which came on Nov. 24. “Luke’s doing all the work with the rest of the staff. Luke is 15-0 right now. I’m not. So it’s the dumbest thing I’ve ever heard, to be honest with you.”
What does being a good or bad player have to do with coaching? Not really connected whatsoever..... I'll bet more good coaches were not the stars of their team.
Dan, it must really be tough being a Lakers' fan these days. I can hear the Boss wailing "Glory Days" in the background.

These are all Steve Kerr.  Walton was a horrible player with the Lakers and I can't believe any team would have him on their coaching staff.  I wish the Warriors would take Mitch Kupchak as well, please Santa give me that early Christmas present
As the Chinese proverb says: Success has many fathers and failure is an orphan.

The Dubs, starting with Curry, are motivated by the pervasive dissing around the NBA by parochial fans who cheer their home teams but don't know much about basketball. So a record set by the Dubs or the NBA championship is just luck or no big deal. No other team has reached 16 to start the season. If Phoenix ever beats that, most Dub fans would cheer because it's great basketball, which is really hard to achieve. We know about playing hard and losing. We don't begrudge any team that achieves greatness. If and when Phoenix reaches a higher level, dub fans won't be sniping with sour grapes. And certainly won't be moving goal posts because we can't see past our home team and just want bragging rights. Two NBA teams reached 15. Dubs are at 18 and don't look like they're about to slow down. Don't know basketball if you're not impressed. And what's to discuss when you don't know enough to acknowledge a significant record? This team is making history -- for all basketball fans. If you're just about the Suns winning, you need to step back and sort things out. This is about basketball. It's not about you. Resenting another team's success, denying their achievement,
is really small and pinched. Hope you're better than that. The Suns deserve better too.
Any prolonged undefeated start to a season is impressive, despite what a bitter Phoenix fan says whose team is part of the record.

The record for most wins at the beginning of a season is up there with most wins at the end of the season.  The only win streak record that counts is 33.  Come back after a month and we'll decide if this issue is worth talking about.
what good guys

Coaching is a team experience so credit should go to the Assistants.

However, if and when the Warriors go on a 7 game losing streak,

no one may want to admit to being the "Head Coach".
The Warrior's biggest controversy is which non-player should get the most credit for their current run. A new meta-level of success.

At least something going right and warms the senses, POSITIVE. Would love to see the Cuban munchkins and baseball play their beloved game and play with camaraderie and sportsmanship with players of our country which is our beloved game too!

I hardly follow baseball before the annual World Series, but many others in the US and Cuba do.  So this is A Good Thing.  I applaud Mr. Schwechheimer's "respectful engagement" and "tranquilo" approach to bring both US and Cuban representatives together, as well as his inclusion of experienced statesmen to interpret subtle cues that help keep the effort stable and ongoing.  Let's have both countries cut through their bureaucratic difficulties and work on getting this done in a fair manner.

On a May, 2002 visit to Cuba, Pres. Carter threw out the first pitch at a Cuban All-Star Game that was coincidentally happening during his trip. I don't think he actually "played," but he has long been an advocate for normalized relations with Cuba.

I cannot find an actual image of this event. That would be good to find.

I always agreed with this comment. So much so that in the 1980s I started a small charitable organization to promote good will through the sport of baseball. We raised donations of new and used baseball mitts, bats, balls, shoes, catcher's gear, and jerseys and distributed them, together with toys and educational supplies, to the most impoverished kids in the Dominican Republic, Nicaragua, Guatemala and Costa Rica. We raised a significant quantity of regalos (gifts) for the kids thanks to the generosity of companies like Mizuno USA and Toys "R" Us. Our efforts were non-political and non-partisan; we were interested only in generating a little fun, smiles and happiness--fleeting though it may have been. I'll never forget pitching to the 14-year-old son of the Sandinista mayor of Corinto. With his dad serving as the catcher sans mask or any other protective gear, and a large crowd cheering the kid on, he smacked my fastballs and curveballs like they were flies on a wall, much to the delight of the crowd and his dad. (Where was Dennis Martinez when he was needed?!!)

Anyway, the only country to deny us entry to do our gift-giving was Cuba. They must have thought we were CIA agents, which is laughable in light of our mistreatment by the Guatemalan government and military. But I did not give up on Cuba. In 2003, while on a business trip to Cuba, I gave an antique mitt to the Castro brothers, whose cooperation I sought for my client, along with a copy of Founding Brothers.
Baseball, rather than gunboat, diplomacy. Bringing peoples together in mutual respect and benefit and joyful engagement: Now that's an idea—in today's world— whose time has definitely come.
You don't seem to realize how irrelevant your comments are.

Nice diplomacy--yet our sports teams' identities remain the one place where we still actively teach racism through stereotypes and racist names. It might be nice if the MLB could get over itself, join the 21st century and move owners like the Dolans(Cleveland "Indians") and all those with indigenous team names under their control to actually make positive changes. They will make more money when they do it, the fans will want the new merchandise. As for the diplomats--which America do y ou want to see rise, an inclusive one or a continuation of the racist one?
The holiday this past week was clearly and generally more accurately showcased in National Geographic's Saints and Strangers and we all know www.RacismIsNotAGame.com

Concerned: your post is offensive. I live in the town where this occurred. Your crude "abortion on demand" statement says something about you, not the people here and not the people at PP who provide healthcare to women in our region.

For your information, this man killed a policeman who was also a pastor with conservative views, plus 11 others. You should be ashamed of yourself.

March 28, 1999 Orioles 3, Cuba 2 in Estado Latinoamericano.
May 3, 1999 Cuba 12, Orioles 6 in Camden Yard.
Does France have 30,000 deaths due to gunshots in a year? We do.
